Award.AwardTitle: Supramolecularly Templated Living REP-ROP Polymerizations and Block Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Celtic art, Boy Scout knots, Mobius strip rings, and M.C. Escher's art have fascinated the viewer and challenged their ability to trace the origin of connectivity. For some time now, mathematicians have described the topology of rings and cyclic overlapping structures with their programmable qualities into the so-called Knot Theory. In polymer science, understanding how long polymer chains become tangled and how to get those tangled chains to dissolve in a solution can result in new materials with interesting physical properties and chemical properties that can extend the applications of plastics, coatings, rubber, and composites. There are many opportunities for training and mentoring future scientists in this interdisciplinary and practical field. This research helps preparing a workforce that solves complex problems and produces valuable products.

This project focuses on the design and synthesis of new catenated polymer and block copolymer compositions via monomer ring opening (RO) and macroinitiator ring expansion polymerizations (REP) or REP-ROP Polymerizations. By utilizing the Knot Theory, it may be possible to obtain various knotted macromolecules, which have controlled entanglements as well as block copolymer composition with high yields and high molecular weight. The approaches towards the synthesis of catenated macromolecules involve: 1) phenanthroline-based macroinitiator templates; 2) homopolymers and block copolymers derived from atom transfer radical polymerization methods and ring closures with atom transfer radical coupling; 3) ring expansion strategies with polycaprolactones; and 4) polymer reactions that modify the side groups and control the composition and interaction parameters of the chains. Characterization methods include nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, MALDI mass sppectrometry, atomic force microscopy, size-exclusion chromatography, and rheometry, which verify the polymer's chemical structure, topology, and phase separation in solution and solid state. Collaborations with polymer physicists, theorists, and rheologists are pursued to harness the properties of the catenated polymers as materials and compatibilizers for practical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supramolecularly Templated Knotty Polymers

 

Intellectual Impact:

Polymers are ubiquitous and they have been the subject of research for new materials properties and methods of processing. There is high interest in new polymer synthesis routes, topologies, mechanisms, and applications. The choices for synthesis go from linear, grafted, and hyperbranched systems. However, there are many other topologies that are of high interest because of its relevance: from understanding entanglement behavior to a practical understanding of polymer viscosity limits. Macromolecular architectures based on cyclic polymerization routes can be achieved by ring-closure or ring-expansion routes.

This project has focused on new approaches to to the macromolecular synthesis of catenanes, macrocycles, and knots based on a rational design of supramolecular macroinitiators that template the ring closure and ring expansion in living polymerization mechanism. By design, templated based on organometallic complexes such as Copper metal and phenanthrolines are able to provide a macroinitiator to grow arms or rings through ring expansion reactions.  This was successfully demonstrated and reported with this project. We have also employed a number of macromolecular and surface characterization studies to define successful synthesis strategies. This included methods to determine the size, the dispersity, the hydrodynamic properties, and their intrinsic solution behavior. Using microscopy methods such as AFM we are able to visualize these rings, catenanes, and knots on surfaces. The end goal is to produce higher throughput synthetic methods that can unlock the utility or rationally entangled and knotted polymers. We have also demonstrated the use of highly efficient and continuous flow synthesis and polymerization methods to show the possibility of doing living free-radical polymerization and copolymerization on surfaces. New hyperbranched polymers and dendrimer hybrid nanoparticles are being examined and will be subject to future research.

Broader Impact:

Polymers are well known as plastics. They can also be associated with rubber or epoxy (elastomers and thermosets respectively). Our society cannot easily function without their availability and there is a high need to bring these materials into a circular economy. It is important to develop new synthesis and characterization protocols for demonstrating new materials that can lead to more practical materials applications. The class of polymers investigated in this project are catenated, macrocyclic, and knotty shapes or topologies. They are an interesting class of polymers and may yet have an important function in our study of interfaces, rheology, bulk material transport, and improvement of thermo-mechanical properties. New methods have also been developed for their efficient synthesis. This project was indeed directed to developing new materials but an important outcome is also the training of graduate students and undergraduate students who will be very skilled in this research. The project has also been used for public outreach in terms of talks to general audience and involvement of high school students with diverse and underrepresented groups. The findings have also been reported in a number of high impact publications and a number of national and international conferences including giving talks at prestigious institutions.

Images (1 of )
  • The exact topologies of polymers can be achieved using supramolecular and knotted templates to produce beautiful macromolecular architectures that are also functional. This is done through ring closure and ring expansion synthesis.
    Rigoberto Advincula
    Copyrighted
    Rigoberto C Advincula
    Templated Catenane and Knotty Polymers
  • The use of continuous flow chemistry and polymerization methods will enable highly efficient and continuous synthesis of polymer materials. This will be applied towards more complex polymer architectures and new mechanisms.
    Rigoberto Advincula
    Copyrighted
    Rigoberto C Advincula
    Continuous Flow Chemistry Polymerization
